claim:
A 60-year-old man presents to the physician for a follow-up examination. During the previous visit, splenomegaly was detected on the abdominal exam, which has been confirmed by abdominal ultrasound. He has no complaints other than fatigue for several months. There is no history of serious illness. His only medication is acetaminophen for knee pain. The temperature is 36.7℃ (98.1℉), pulse is 68, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. On physical examination, the spleen size on percussion is 16 cm (6.2 in). Otherwise, the physical examination shows no abnormalities. The laboratory test results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 10 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3
Leukocyte count 80,000/mm3
Platelet count 450,000/mm3
The peripheral blood smear shows a predominance of neutrophils and the presence of band cells, myelocytes, promyelocytes, and blasts (< 5%). The cytogenetic study shows t(9;22). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? : Chronic myeloid leukemia

supporting.text: The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) is pathognomonic for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

attacks.text: The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) is pathognomonic for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
While t(9;22) is common in CML, it is not exclusive to CML and can also occur in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) or acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
The patient's fatigue and splenomegaly could also be caused by myelofibrosis, which can present with similar symptoms and lab findings but without t(9;22).
The presence of blasts (<5%) and the spectrum of immature myeloid cells (band cells, myelocytes, promyelocytes) strongly supports CML over ALL or AML, where blast counts are typically higher.
Myelofibrosis typically presents with teardrop cells on peripheral smear and bone marrow fibrosis, neither of which are mentioned in this case, making CML more likely.
In rare cases, ALL or AML with t(9;22) can present with low blast counts, especially in early stages, so further molecular testing (e.g., BCR-ABL1 quantification) is needed for definitive diagnosis.
Primary myelofibrosis can occasionally present without classic teardrop cells early in the disease course, so bone marrow biopsy would be required to definitively exclude it.

supporting.text: The peripheral blood smear findings, including the presence of immature myeloid cells (myelocytes, promyelocytes, and blasts), are highly suggestive of CML.

attacks.text: The peripheral blood smear findings, including the presence of immature myeloid cells (myelocytes, promyelocytes, and blasts), are highly suggestive of CML.
The presence of t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome) is pathognomonic for CML, further supporting the diagnosis.
The marked leukocytosis with a left shift and splenomegaly are classic features of CML, making other diagnoses less likely.
While t(9;22) is characteristic of CML, it can also occur in some cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which should be ruled out.
The absence of B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss) and the relatively stable clinical presentation could suggest a more indolent myeloproliferative disorder.
The presence of <5% blasts in the peripheral blood makes ALL less likely, as ALL typically presents with a higher blast count.
The marked leukocytosis and splenomegaly are not typical of indolent myeloproliferative disorders, which usually present with milder leukocytosis and less prominent splenomegaly.

supporting.text: The marked leukocytosis (80,000/mm3) with a predominance of neutrophils is a classic feature of CML.

attacks.text: The marked leukocytosis (80,000/mm3) with a predominance of neutrophils is a classic feature of CML.
Leukocytosis can also occur in infections or inflammatory conditions, which may not necessarily indicate CML.
The presence of t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome) is pathognomonic for CML and strongly supports the diagnosis.
Infections typically present with fever and other systemic symptoms, which are absent in this patient.
The presence of immature cells (myelocytes, promyelocytes, and blasts) in the peripheral smear is more indicative of a myeloproliferative disorder like CML than an infection.
Some chronic infections or inflammatory conditions can present without fever, making infection still a possible differential.

supporting.text: Splenomegaly is a common physical finding in CML due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

attacks.text: Splenomegaly is a common physical finding in CML due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
Splenomegaly is not specific to CML and can occur in other conditions such as myelofibrosis or infections.
The presence of t(9;22) is highly specific for CML, making splenomegaly more likely to be due to CML in this context.
Myelofibrosis also commonly presents with splenomegaly and can sometimes mimic CML in early stages.
Infections like mononucleosis can cause splenomegaly but would typically present with other symptoms such as fever or lymphadenopathy, which are absent here.
The high leukocyte count with left shift and presence of t(9;22) strongly support CML over other causes of splenomegaly.
Early myelofibrosis may not yet show the characteristic bone marrow fibrosis, making it harder to distinguish from CML initially.
The absence of fever and lymphadenopathy makes infectious causes less likely, reinforcing CML as the diagnosis.

supporting.text: The patient's fatigue and mild anemia (hemoglobin 10 g/dL) are consistent with the early stages of CML.

attacks.text: The patient's fatigue and mild anemia (hemoglobin 10 g/dL) are consistent with the early stages of CML.
Fatigue and mild anemia are nonspecific symptoms and can occur in many other conditions, such as iron deficiency anemia or chronic infections, not just CML.
The presence of splenomegaly and leukocytosis with a left shift is more indicative of a myeloproliferative disorder like CML than just fatigue and anemia.
Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic anemia (low MCV), whereas this patient has a normal MCV, making it less likely.
Chronic infections usually present with other systemic symptoms like fever or weight loss, which are absent in this patient.
The t(9;22) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome) is pathognomonic for CML, strongly supporting the diagnosis over other myeloproliferative disorders.
While t(9;22) is classic for CML, it can also rarely occur in other conditions like acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), so further testing is needed to confirm CML.

supporting.text: The absence of fever, night sweats, or significant weight loss argues against an acute leukemia or aggressive lymphoma.

attacks.text: The absence of fever, night sweats, or significant weight loss argues against an acute leukemia or aggressive lymphoma.
The presence of splenomegaly and marked leukocytosis with a left shift is highly suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), regardless of the absence of B symptoms.
The t(9;22) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome) is pathognomonic for CML, which overrides the absence of B symptoms in the diagnostic process.
While t(9;22) is characteristic of CML, it can also occur in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which may present without B symptoms in early stages.
Splenomegaly and leukocytosis can also occur in myelofibrosis, which may not present with B symptoms initially.
The peripheral blood smear showing <5% blasts strongly argues against acute leukemia (ALL or AML), supporting CML as the more likely diagnosis.
Myelofibrosis typically presents with teardrop cells and significant fibrosis on bone marrow biopsy, which are absent in this case.

supporting.text: The platelet count is elevated (450,000/mm3), which can be seen in CML but is not specific and could suggest other myeloproliferative disorders.

attacks.text: The platelet count is elevated (450,000/mm3), which can be seen in CML but is not specific and could suggest other myeloproliferative disorders.
The presence of t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome) is highly specific for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), strongly supporting this diagnosis over other myeloproliferative disorders.
The peripheral blood smear findings (neutrophils, band cells, myelocytes, promyelocytes, and blasts) are classic for CML and less common in other myeloproliferative disorders.
While t(9;22) is specific for CML, rare cases of other myeloproliferative disorders may also present with similar cytogenetic abnormalities, reducing its absolute specificity.
The leukocyte count of 80,000/mm3 is more consistent with CML than other myeloproliferative disorders, which typically present with lower leukocyte counts.
The rarity of t(9;22) in non-CML myeloproliferative disorders makes it an extremely reliable diagnostic marker for CML, outweighing the possibility of other conditions.

supporting.text: The normal mean corpuscular volume (90 μm3) makes nutritional deficiencies (e.g., B12 or folate deficiency) less likely as a cause of the anemia.

attacks.text: The normal mean corpuscular volume (90 μm3) makes nutritional deficiencies (e.g., B12 or folate deficiency) less likely as a cause of the anemia.
While the MCV is normal, B12 or folate deficiency can sometimes present with normocytic anemia, especially in early stages or with concurrent conditions.
The presence of splenomegaly and marked leukocytosis with left-shifted myeloid series strongly suggests a myeloproliferative disorder like CML, overshadowing nutritional causes.
Early B12 deficiency can indeed present with normocytic anemia, but the absence of hypersegmented neutrophils on the smear makes this less likely.
The t(9;22) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome) is pathognomonic for CML, which fully explains all findings and eliminates the need to consider nutritional deficiencies.
Hypersegmented neutrophils may not always be present in early B12 deficiency, so their absence doesn't completely rule it out.
The degree of leukocytosis (80,000/mm3) and presence of immature myeloid cells are far more characteristic of CML than any nutritional deficiency.
